projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: ARTICLES TO BE ENQVIRED OF, BY THE MINISTER, CHVRCH-WARDENS AND SIDE-MEN, OF EVERY PARISH WITHIN THE ARCHDEACONRY OF LONDON.

WHICH WERE GIVEN IN CHARGE, IN the annuall Visitation of the Right Worshipfull Mr. Theophilus Allmer. Doctor of Diuinitie, Archdeacon of LONDON, in the yeare of our Lord GOD, one thousand sixe hundred and twentie.
LONDON, ❧ Printed by Thomas Purfoot. (1620.)

div.head:
A BRANCH OF THE STA
• ute made in the first yeare of the Raigne of our late Soueraigne Lady Queene ELIZABETH, intituled an Act for the vniformity of Common Prayer, and Seruice of the Church.
div.p:
THat from and after the feast of the Natiuity of S. Iohn Baptist next comming, all and euery person, and persons inhabiting within this Realme, or any other the Queenes Maiesties dominions, shall •• ligently & faithfully (hauing no lawfull or reasonable •• cuse to be absent) indeauour themselues to resort to their Parish Church, or Chappell accustomed, or vpon reasonable let therof, to some vsual place where Common Prayer, and such like seruice of God shall be vsed in such time of let, vpon euery Sunday, and other dayes ordained and vsed to be kept as holidaies, and then and there to abide orderly, and soberly during the time of Common Prayer, preaching, or other seruice of God, there to be vsed and ministred, vpon paine of punishment by the censures of the Church; and also vpon
paine that euery person so offending, shall forfeit for •
uery such offence twelue pence, to bee leuied by th • Churchwardens of the Parish where such offence sha •• be done, to the vse of the poore of the same Parish, 〈◊〉 the goods, lands, and Tenements of such offendor, b •• way of distresse. And for due execution hereof, th • Queenes most excellent Maiestie, the Lords temporal • and all the Commons in this present Parliament assembled, doe in Gods name earnestly require and charge al • Arch-Bishops, Bishops, and other Ordinaries, that the shall indeauour themselues to the vttermost of thei • knowledge, that the true and due execution hereof ma •• be had throughout their Diocesse, and charges, as 〈◊〉 they will answere before God, for such euills and plagues wherewith Almighty God may iustly punish his people, for neglecting this good and wholesome law.

div.head: The forme of the Oath to be ministred vnto the Church-wardens onely.
div.p: YOu shall sweare, that you shall duely and faithfully administer, and dispose of the Stock, and goods belonging to your Parish Church, which shall come to your hands and possession, to and for the best benefit of your Church; and in the end of your office of Church warden-ship, you shall make a true, iust, and perfect accompt thereof; and yeeld, and deliuer the remainder thereupon, into the hands, and custody of those persons who shall succeede you in the same Office, So helpe you God, and his faithfull promises in Iesus Christ.

div.head: The forme of the Oath to be ministred vnto the Church-wardens, and Side-menioyntly.
div.p: YOu shall sweare, that you, and euery of you, shall duly consider, and diligently inquire of all these Articles giuen you in charge, and that all fauour, hatred, hope, feare, or any other corrupt affection set aside, you shall present vnto vs, or our Officiall, all and euery such person which now is, or lately was in your Parish, as haue committed any offence, or default comprised in any of these Articles, or which are vehemently suspected or diffamed of any such offence, or default. Wherein you shall deale according to an vpright conscience, neither presenting, nor sparing to present any person contrary to truth; hauing in this action God before your eyes, with an earnest zeale to maintaine truth, and to suppresse vice. So helpe you God, and his faithfull promises in Iesus Christ.

div.head: The charge of you the Church-wardens and Side-men, set downe for the better performance of your duties, and discharge of your OATHS.
div.p: YOu are straightly charged, that within the space of one weeke 〈◊〉 the farthest, next ensuing this your admission, by vs, or our authority, into this your Office; and after the same, once in euery moneth at the least, during your said Office, you do diligently 〈◊〉 carefully reade, or heare to beread, and duely consider of all, and euery of these subsequent Articles, now giuen you in charge; and also tha • you doe diligently and carefully endeauour to enquire, and know a •• offences and offenders, against the same Articles. Which being we •• obserued, you shall be readily prepared to disburthen your consciences in this behalfe.

And that at fit seasons you doe meet together, and conferre with you • Minister about, and require him to be assistant vnto you, in the true vnderstanding, and detecting of sinne, and the breach of his Maiesties lawes Ecclesiasticall established; that so condigne punishment may be inflicted on the offenders, and their reformation be effected. Your Minister being deepely charged in this behalfe, in, and by the 26. Canon Ecclesiasticall, lately ordained.

And lastly, that in your presentments to be made, you doe specifi 〈◊〉 the fault, or crime, proper name, and sir-name, trade or profession, and place of dwelling of euery person presented. And that you shal bring your first generall presentment vpon all the said Articles, into Christ-Church in London, in the forenoone, betweene the houres of eight, and eleauen of the clocke, on the three and twentieth day of September, Anno Dom. 1620. and your last generall presentment on the Tuesday Senight immediately ensuing after Easter day next, according to the tenor of the 118. Canon, or else then, and there to appeare personally, to shew the cause of your default therein.
Intimating vnto you further, that you may (besides those generall presentments) present offenders as often as you shall thinke meet, as by the 116. Canon is prescribed.

div.head: ARTICLES TO BE ENQVIred of by the Minister, Churchwardens, and Side-men, within the Archdeaconry of LONDON.
Concerning the Church.
div.p:
WHETHER haue you in your Church all things requisite for the Common Prayer, and due administration of the Sacraments, according to his Maiesties lawes, and Canons Ecclesiasticall lately established? and namely, a faire Bible, Canon. 80 the booke of Common Prayer lately ordained onely to be vsed, Canon. 81 a Font of stone set 〈◊〉 in the ancient vsuall place, Canon. 82 a decent Communion table standing ••• n a frame, with a Carpet of Silke, or some other séemely stuffe, 〈◊〉 a faire Linnen cloth to lay thereon at the time of the Communi
•• , a faire Communion cup with a couer of siluer, a decent Pulpit • ith a cloth and Cushion for the same, Canon. 83 a conuenient Pulpit or seat to • ade seruice in, a comely large Surplisse, Canon. 84 a strong Chest for almes for 〈◊〉 poore, hauing thrée lockes and keies, and another Chest for kéeping 〈◊〉 the Ornaments of the Church, & the Church Register booke? & whe
•• er haue you a Register booke of Parchment, of all Christnings, Canon. 70 wed
••• gs, and burials? and whether is the same kept according to the •• anous? and whether doth your Minister vpon euery Sunday reade 〈◊〉 names of such as haue béene Christened, married, or buried the 〈◊〉
• e before?

2 Whether your Church, Chancell, and Churchyard be kept in good Canon. 85
•• parations, aswell within, as without? Canon. 88 whether any prophanation 〈◊〉 vsed in thē, or any man hath incroached vpon them? & whether your • arsonage or Vicarage house, and all the housing thereunto belong
•• g, be likewise maintained in sufficient reparations? If not, through • hese default is it? and what is the defect?

Whether haue you a Terrier of all the Gleabes, Lands, Canon. 87 Mea
•• es, Gardens, Orchards, Houses, Stockes, Implements, Tenements,
and portions of tythes lying within, or without your ••
rish; which belong vnto your Parsonage or Vicarage, and in wh ••• hands it doth remaine? If not, you shall together with your Mini ••• make diligent inquiry of all the premisses, and exhibite with your 〈◊〉 presentment a true note of them in parchment, subcribed with y •• hands, specifying how they are buttalled and bounded, and in wh • accupation at this present they are?

div.head: Concerning the Minister.
div.p:
4 WHether diuine seruice be said in your Church by your ••
nister distinctly and reuerently, Canon. 14 on all Sundayes, and h ••• dayes appointed to be obserued by the lawes of England, and on th •• Eeues, Canon. 15 and on Wednesdays and Fridays at conuenient vsuall time and whether doth hee in ministring the Sacraments, solemnizing 〈◊〉 Matrimony, visitation of the sicke, burying the dead, churching of 〈◊〉 men, and all other Rites and offices of the Church, vse the formes 〈◊〉 Prayers prescribed in the booke of Common Prayers, without any •
mission or addition? and whether doth he reade the booke of Cano • once yearely, Canon. 58 and were a Surplisse according to the Canon?

5 Whether doth your Minister solemnly giue warning to his P •
rishioners for the administration of the holy Communion, Canon. 22 and for t ••• obseruation Canon. 64 of all holidayes, and fasting dayes? and whether doth 〈◊〉 visite Canon. 67 the sicke, & exhort them to gius to the poore? and whether doth 〈◊〉 conferre Canon. 84 with Recusants in your Parish (if there be any) according 〈◊〉 the Canons? Canon. 66 and whether doth he admit to the holy Communion a •• notorious Canon. 26 offenders, Schismatickes, or strangers, or rei • ct any w •••• are not Canon. 27 by presentment, or publike scandall infamous for some notor •
ous crime? Canon. 28 and whether doth he admit any Father to be Godfath •• to his owne Canon. 29 childe, or any to be Godfathers and Godmothers, whi •• haue not receiued the holy Communion? and whether doth he not v ••• the signé of the crosse in baptisme, or doth baptize in any Bason, or 〈◊〉 ther vessell, and not in the vsuall Font, or doth baptize in any childr ••• that were not Canon. 62 borne within the Parish? Canon. 63 and whether doth he mar ••• any in any exempt place, or without Banes published thrée seuer •• Sundayes or holidays, or without a sufficient dispensation or licens •• or without license in times prohibited, albeit the Banes were thre •• published, or not, betwéene the houres of eight & twelue in the for noone, Canon. 100 or (if the parties be vnder the age of One and Twenty yeare •• before their Parents or Cournors haue signified their consent 〈◊〉
〈◊〉 and whether doth he refuse to christen, or to burie, Canon. 68 or deser the 〈◊〉 longer then he should? and whether by his default any child Canon. 69
〈◊〉 dyed without baptisme in your Parish?

6 Whether doth hee preach, minister the Communion, Canon. 71 baptize children, vnlesse in case of necessity, solemnize marriage, or church •• omen in priuate houses? Canon. 71 or doth he kéepe or suffer any Fasts, pro
•• hesies, Exercises, or Exorcismes, without lawfull authority? Canon. 73 or doth he hold or suffer any priuate conuenticles contrary to the Canons? and whether doth he frequent Tauernes, Alehouses, Canon. 75 or any • lace suspected for incontinency? or doth he table or lodge in any •• ath house? or is he a common gamster at Dice, Cards, Tables, or any other vnlawfull game? or is he a swearer, or drunkard, or one that applyeth not himselfe to his studie, or is otherwise offensiue, or standalous to his function, and ministry? Canon. 74 or doth not he vse derency in his apparell, as by the Canons he is enioyned?

7 Whether is he continually resident vpon his Benefice? Canon. 45 or how long time hath he béene absent from the same? and (in case hee hée licensed to be absent) whether doth he cause his Cure to be sufficiently supplied according to the Canons? Canon. 47 whether (if he be a Preacher allowed) doth he preach one sermon euery Sunday, Canon. 46 or (if not so allowed) doth he procure monthly Sermons, and reade Homilies? and whether (not being so allowed) doth he expound any Scripture, Canon. 49 or suffer any man to preach in your Church, whom you haue not well knowne to haue béene sufficiently licensed, and who hath not first subscribed his name, together with the day when he did preach, and who was not soberly or decently apparelled? Canon. 74

8 Whether your Preacher Canon. 56 and Lecturer reade diuine Seruice, and minister the Sacraments twise in the yeare at the least, in his owne person, according to the Canons? Canon. 55 and whether doth hee vse the forme of Prayer, before his Sermon, for the Kings most excellent Maiesty, exhorting the people to obedience to his Maiestie, and • ther Magistrates in authority vnder him?

9. Whether doth your Minister on Sundaies and holidayes catechise the youth and ignorant persons in your Parish, Canon. 59 according to the order prescribed in the beake of Common Prayer, and according to the Canons? and whether doth he in the Rogation dayes vse the pera • bulation of the rircuite of the Parish, appointed by the law, according to his dutie?

10 Whether doth he euery sixe moneths denounce in your Parish
Church, Canon. 65 all such of your Parish as dot perseuere in the sentence 〈◊〉 Excommunication, not sée king to be absolued? and whether hat • he admitted any such Excommunicate person to the Communion or to the Church, without Certificate of his absolution: and whether doth he, or any of your Parish, familiarly frequent the company of any such excommunicate person?

div.head: Concerning Parishioners.
div.p:
11 WHether any of your Parishioners one not cause their children, Canon. 59 seruants, and Apprentices to come to their Minister vpon Sundayes and holidayes, to be instructed in the Ga
•
iechsme by him? and whether any of them refuse or neglect to come, or comming, refuse to learne those instructions set forth in the booke of Common Prayer? and what be the names of them so not causing, or refusing?

12 Whether any of your parishioners, Canon. 13 or other strangers soiourning, lodging, or commonly resorting to any house within your Parish, being aboue Sixteene yeares of age, do wilfully or negligently absent themselues from your Parish Church, vpon Sundayes, or holidayes, at Morning and Euening prayer? or who come very late to Church vpon the said dayes? or who depart from Church before the diuine Seruice be finished? Canon. 18 or who doe not reuerently behaue themselues during the time of diuine Seruice, deuoutly knoeling at such times as the generall confession of sinnes, the Letany, the ten Commandements, and all prayers and Collects are read? and what Men, Youthes, and Boyes, during all that time, haue not had their heads wholly vncouered, except in case of apparant sicknesse? and who doe vse any gaming or pastime abroad, or in any house, or doe sit in the stréet, or Churchyard, or in any Tauerne or Victualling house, vpō any of those days in ye time of diuine seruice? and who haue quarrelled, brawled, or vsed violence to any person within your Church, or Churchyard? and who haue vsed filthy and prophane talke, or other rude and immodest behauiour? and what be the names of the offenders herein?

13 Whether there be any of, Canon. 21 or within your Parish, being Sixteene yeares of age, and vpward, that doe not receine the holy Communion in your Church thrice in this yeare at the least, and chiefty once at Caster next? and whether any of your Parish doe not deuoutly
knéele at the receiuing thereof? and whether doth not your •• nister receiue it himself? on euery day that he administreth it to 〈◊〉 , and vse the words of Institution at euery time yt the Bread ••• ine is administred? and whether haue all those persons which •••• e béen partakers of the holy Communion, signified their names • nto the Minister, or vnto some other person by him thereunto ap
• ointed oner-night, or else in the morning before the beginning of Morning prayers, according to the forme prescribed in the booke of Common Prayers aforesaid, to the intent that the Minister, and all • thers appointed to haue the charge and care thereof, may fully bée •• vertised, and take notice (in due time) of all them that haue •• éne Communicants, and of all them that haue not béen Communicants at the time and times appointed for the same? Canon. 22 To which purpose, that the people may be prepared so to doe, the Minister shall giue publike warning thereof in the Church, on the next Sunday before the Communion shall be celebrated. And whether doe your selues diligently obserue your office, in marking what persons of or within your Parish offend against this, and the next precedent Article, in due presenting of their names?

14 Whether any in your Parish hauing a Preacher to their Parson, Uicar, or Curate, doe absent themselues from his Sermons, and resort to other places to heare other Preachers? and whether any hauing béene ordained Prieff, or Deacon, hath relinquished the same, and betaken himselfe to a course of life as a Lay man? And whether any (not being in Orders) do openly reade common Prayer, or execute any ministeriall dutie in the Church, and what bée their names?

15 Whether there be any that doe publikely or priuately speake against the booke of Common Prayer, deprauing the same, Canon. 4 or any therein contained? or doe so speake against, or depraue any Canon. 6 of the Articles of Religion, agréed vpon in Anno Dom. 1562? Canon. 2 or against the Kings rovall Supremacie in causes Ecclesiasticall? or against Canon. 30 any of the Rites or Ceremonies of the Church of England? or against the gouernment of the said Church of England, vnder the kings most excellent Maiestie, by Archbishops, Bishops, Deanes, Canon. 7 Archdeacon • , and other Officers thereunto lawfully appointed, affirming that the same is repugnant to the word of God, and that the said Ecclesiasticall Officers are not lawfully ordained? or whether there be any that be Authors, or Maintainers of Schisme, Canon. 9 or 〈2+ pages missing〉
any persons in their houses, Canon. 6 to eate, drinke, or play at any game during the time of diuine Seruice, or Sermon on those dayes? an • you are to specifie the offences, and offenders.

24 Whether doe any in your Parish familiarly frequent th •• company of excommunicate persons? and whether doth your Minister, or any of your Parish, without consent of your Ordinary, cause any to doe penance? or to be censured or punished by any Vestrie méetings, or otherwise by their owne authority? or one or haue taken any money for any crime or matter punishable by the Ecclesiasticall lawes? and you are to specifie the names of them that haue béene so punished, and in what manner, and vpon what cause.

25 Whether haue you, and euery of you the Churcwardens, and Sidemen, within the space of one wéeke next and immediately ensuing your admission (by vs, or our authority) into this your Office, and sithence the same, once in euery moneth at the least, diligently and carefully rea • y, or heare read, and duely considered of all and euery of these Articles giuen you in charge? and whether haue you, and euery of you diligently and carefully endeauoured to inquire and know the offences and offenders, against any of the contents of these Articles? and whether haue you duely presented all and euery of them, vnto vs the Archdeacon of London your Ordinary, or vnto our Officiall, according to your seuerall oaths, by vs, or our authority in this behalfe, administred vnto you? and if any one, or more of you the Churchwardens, Canon. 117 and Sidemen, doe know, or haue heard of any fault inquired of in these Articles, or of any other crime (the reformation whereof belongeth to the Ecclesiasticall Zurisdiction) happening from the Fiue and twentieth day of March. Anno Dom. 1620. that then you shall informe one another thereof. and shall likewise present the same, by vertue of your oaths taken as aforesaid.

Whether haue you the Churchwardens, and Sidemen, at fif seasons, Canon. 26 met togethers, and (in the presence of your Minister) conferred of your presentments to be made vpon, and your answers vnto euery of these preceding Articles? and whether haue you required your Minister, Canon. 113 to be present with you, and to assist you at those times? In •• mating hereby, that if you will not present, according to your o ••• s, and charge, your Minister may himselfe present vnto vs, or ••• Officiall, such faults and crimes as are before particularly
inquired of, in these precedent Articles, for the due refornation of the same

p.hi: WHereas in diuers great Parishes within the Archdeaconry of London, multitudes of people vsually come to receiue the holy C ••• nunion, some of whome are persons excommunicated: It is thought to be very conuenient, that in euery Parish the names of all such persons excommunicated, be alwayes kept in writing, from time to time. That so the Minister (when he is to administer that holy Sacrament) may thereby be remembred of those persons excommunicated, and so auoyde them.
